title-group.article-title: Renal Cell Carcinoma With Extensive Oncocytic Features

abstract.p: Oncocytic features are a hallmark of renal oncocytoma, but can be seen in other renal tumors such as clear cell renal cell carcinoma with granular cells and eosinophilic variant of chromophobe cell tumors. Also a recent morphological variant of mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma with oncocytic changes has been described, adding another challenge. Here we report an unusual case of unclassified renal cell carcinoma with extensive oncocytic changes and we discuss the differential diagnosis.

body.p: Oncocytic features are a hallmark of renal oncocytoma but can be seen in other renal tumors such as clear cell renal cell carcinoma with granular cells and eosinophilic variant of chromophobe cell tumors. Up to 5% of renal neoplasms are ultimately diagnosed as unclassified renal cell carcinoma with oncocytic features accounting for a significant number of these tumors. Also, a recent morphological variant of mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma with oncocytic changes has been described, adding another challenge. Here, we report an unusual case of renal cell carcinoma with extensive oncocytic changes, and we discuss the differential diagnosis.

A 53-year-old woman presented with a large umbilical hernia and was found to have a 5.4-cm heterogeneously enhancing right renal mass. The radiologist raised the possibility of renal cell carcinoma or an oncocytoma (Figure 1).

Based on these findings, she underwent right nephrectomy and umbilical hernia repair. The specimen received consisted of a right kidney that measured 15.0 × 11.0 × 9.0 cm. The specimen was bivalved to reveal a bulging well-delineated mass that was involving the midpole. The tumor measured 6.4 × 5.8 × 5.2 cm. It replaced approximately 60% of the renal parenchyma. The cut surface of the tumor was variegated bright yellow-white with foci of hemorrhage and necrosis.

Histologically, the tumor consisted of closely packed areas of small tubules with oncocytic cytoplasm (Figure 2), papillary structures, focal clear cell changes, paucity of spindle cell differentiation, intertubular foam cells, and psammomatous calcifications (Figure 3) in a background of mucinous stroma. The oncocytic changes involved more than 90% of the tumor cells (Figure 4).

Since the tumor has this unique morphology, the case was reviewed by 2 experts in renal pathology. Based on this variation in morphology, the differential diagnosis was mucinous tubular and spindle cell carcinoma (MTSC) with variant morphology and unclassified renal cell carcinoma. Papillary renal cell carcinoma was also considered given the overlapping features between papillary renal cell carcinoma and MSTC. Taking into consideration all these findings and the absence of trisomy of chromosome 7 and 17 (performed by fluorescence in situ hybridization), the diagnosis of unclassified renal cell carcinoma with features mimicking MTSC is favored. MTSC is a new rare morphological variant of renal cell carcinoma introduced by the most recent World Health Organization classification on renal tumors.1

He et al2 described this tumor for the first time in 1998 as an “unclassified renal cell carcinoma with histology mimicking lower-nephron nephrogenesis.” Subsequent reports have described renal tumors with similar clinical, histological and immunohistochemical features under different entities, such as “low-grade renal cell carcinoma arising from the lower nephron,” “low-grade myxoid renal epithelial neoplasms with distal nephron differentiation,” and “spindle and cuboidal renal cell carcinoma.”3-7 The first formal series of MTSC was described by Parwani et al.5 In the 2004 World Health Organization classification of renal tumors, MTSCs are described as low-grade tumors with a favorable prognosis, with a wide age range (17-82 years), and a female preponderance.1,7 These tumors are composed of tightly packed small, elongated tubules separated by mucinous stroma. Like other renal tumors, it typically presents as an asymptomatic mass, although flank pain and hematuria may occur. The most current data imply that the majority of MTSCs have a favorable prognosis. However, the true biologic behavior is unclear at this time.

Fine et al8 expanded the histological spectrum of MTSC, describing new features of MTSCs and absence of the typical abundant extracellular matrix in some cases, which they termed a mucin-poor variant of MTSC. They also noted that aggregate of foam cells, calcifications, oncocytic changes, and focal papillations are relatively common. However, the presence of well-formed papillae and psammomatous classification are rare.

In this study of 17 cases, 7 were considered mucin-poor MTSCs, 9 showed foamy macrophages, 2 showed abundant eosinophilic/oncocytic cytoplasm, 6 revealed areas of papillation, heterotopic bone, and focal psammomatous calcifications, and 1 case revealed well-formed papillae.8
MTSCs with focal neuroendocrine differentiation and sarcomatoid differentiation have also been reported, adding to the variety of subtypes associated with this entity.7,9

On the other hand, given the extensive morphologic and immunohistochemical overlap between papillary renal cell carcinoma and MSTC, it was suggested that MSTC may represent a variant of papillary cell carcinoma. In a study performed by Argani et al,10 it was concluded that these 2 types are distinct as supported by clinical, morphologic, and genetic analysis. Multiple studies have shown that MSTC lack the trisomies of chromosomes 7 and 17.

Finally, renal cell carcinoma unclassified should be assigned when the renal cell carcinoma does not fill readily into one of the other categories. It amounts to 4% to 5% of cases in surgical series.1 Oncocytic tumors account for a significant number of this category.

In summary, we report renal cell carcinoma with an unusual morphology. The unusual histologic picture of this tumor can be very challenging. Careful examination and fluorescence in situ hybridization studies are required for definitive diagnosis. Because of extensive variations in histological features, renal tumors with features of MTSC require careful histological examination and judicious use of immunohistochemical stains to exclude other histological types of renal cell carcinoma.
